{{Infobox mass murderer | name = Maurice Clemmons | image = Maurice Clemmons mugshot.jpg | image_size = 210px | caption = Mugshot of Maurice Clemmons | birthname = | occupation = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1972|02|06}} | birth_place= [[North Little Rock, Arkansas|North Little Rock]], [[Arkansas]], United States | death_date = {{Death date and age|2009|12|01|1972|02|06}} | death_place= [[Seattle, Washington]], U.S. | cause = Gunshot wounds from police | spouse = Nicole Smith (2004–09; his death) | targets = [[2009 shooting of Lakewood, Washington, police officers|Four police officers]] | locations = [[Parkland, Washington]] | fatalities = 4 | weapons = * [[Glock 17]] [[handgun]] * [[Smith & Wesson]] [[.38 Special|.38-caliber]] [[revolver]] }}
'''Maurice Clemmons''' (February 6, 1972 – December 1, 2009) was the shooter in the November 29, 2009 [[2009 shooting of Lakewood, Washington, police officers|murder of four police officers]] in [[Parkland, Washington]].<ref name="Naughton1130"/> After evading police for two days following the shooting, Clemmons was shot and killed by a [[Seattle Police Department|police officer]] in [[Seattle]].
Prior to his involvement in the shooting, Clemmons had at least five felony convictions in [[Arkansas]] and at least eight felony charges in [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]].<ref name="Buck1130"/> His first incarceration began in 1989, at age 17. Facing sentences totaling 108 years in prison, the burglary sentences were reduced in 2000 by [[Governor of Arkansas]] [[Mike Huckabee]] to 47 years, which made him immediately eligible for parole. The Arkansas Parole Board unanimously moved to release him in 2000. Clemmons was subsequently arrested on other charges and was jailed several times. In the months prior to the Parkland shooting, he was in jail on charges of [[assault]]ing a police officer and [[rape|raping]] a child. One week prior to the Parkland shooting, he was released from jail after posting a $150,000 [[bail bond]].
At the time, Clemmons' murder of four police officers represented the largest number of law enforcement officers killed by a lone perpetrator in a single incident in U.S. history. It was surpassed in July 2016 when [[2016 shooting of Dallas police officers|a mass shooting]] occurred in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]], resulting in the deaths of five police officers.
==Early life and crimes== Maurice Clemmons's father made frames for automobile seats at a [[Chrysler]] factory,<ref name="STimes1206">{{Cite news|title=A path to murder: The story of Maurice Clemmons |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |date=December 6, 2009 |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010436039_clemmonsprofile06m.html |accessdate=January 31, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091209021105/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010436039_clemmonsprofile06m.html |archivedate=December 9, 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Maurice Clemmons' uncle says he changed |work=[[Associated Press]] |date=December 2, 2009 |url=http://www.king5.com/internal?st=print&id=78353117&path=/news |accessdate=January 31, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613200255/http://www.king5.com/internal?st=print&id=78353117&path=%2Fnews |archivedate=June 13, 2011 |df= }}</ref> and his mother, Dorothy Mae Clemmons,<ref name="STimes1206" /> worked in a nursing home.<ref name="ST1129">{{Cite news|title=Suspect let out of Pierce County jail one week ago |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |date=2009-11-29 |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010386501_clemmons30m.html |accessdate=2009-11-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091203102157/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010386501_clemmons30m.html |archivedate=2009-12-03 |df= }}</ref> He had five siblings.<ref name="STimes1206" /> Clemmons lived in [[Marianna, Arkansas]] in his early youth, and moved to [[Little Rock, Arkansas|Little Rock]] as a teen. He was arrested when he was a [[Eleventh grade|junior]] at [[Hall High School (Arkansas)|Hall High School]] for carrying a [[.25 ACP|.25-caliber]] pistol on school property.<ref name="ST1129" /><ref name="Brunner1130">{{Cite news|last1=Brunner |first1=Jim |last2=Kelleher |first2=Susan |title=Persuasive appeal helped Clemmons win clemency |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |date=2009-11-30 |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010392867_shootingclemency01m.html |accessdate=2009-12-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091204011054/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010392867_shootingclemency01m.html |archivedate=2009-12-04 |df= }}</ref> He claimed to be carrying the gun because he was "beaten by dopers", and said he had "something for them" if they attacked him again.<ref name="ST1129" /> Clemmons did not return to school, and finished his education at eleventh grade.<ref>{{Citation |date=January 13, 2000 |title=Executive Clemency Interview Worksheet |publication-place=[[Little Rock, Arkansas]] |publisher=Arkansas Board of Parole |page=5 }}</ref> In 1989, a 17-year-old Clemmons and two other accomplices robbed a woman at midnight in the parking lot of a Little Rock hotel bar. Clemmons pretended to have a gun in his pocket and threatened to shoot her if she did not give him her purse. When she responded, "Well, why don't you just shoot?", he punched her in the head and ran off with the purse, which contained $16 and a credit card.<ref name="Brunner1130" />
Clemmons was accused multiple times of displaying violent behavior during court appearances. In one incident, he dismantled a metal door stop and hid it in his sock to use as a weapon. It was discovered and confiscated by a court bailiff. In another incident, he took a lock from his holding cell and threw it at a bailiff, but missed and accidentally hit his mother instead.<ref name="ST1129" /><ref name="Brunner1130" /> Clemmons was once accused of reaching for a guard's pistol while being transported to court. During one trial, he was shackled in leg irons and seated next to a uniformed officer because the presiding judge ordered extra security, claiming Clemmons had threatened him.<ref name="ST1129" /> At age 16, Clemmons' charges were committed from juvenile court to adult court due to the extremely violent nature of his crimes and demeanor.<ref name="Robinson1201">{{Cite news |last=Robinson |first=Sean |title=Clemmons deemed "dangerous" by psychologists |work=[[The News Tribune]] |date=2009-12-01 |url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/293/story/975661.html?storylink=omni_popular |accessdate=2009-12-02}} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
By 1990, Clemmons was sentenced to 108 years in prison for eight felony charges from his teenage years in Arkansas. The total prison term stemmed from multiple sentences, some of which were concurrent to others and some were consecutive.<ref name="Robinson1201"/><ref name="Brantley1130">{{Cite news|last=Brantley|first=Max|title=Maurice Clemmons' record UPDATE|date=2009-11-30|work=[[Arkansas Times]]}}</ref> The largest sentencing came in 1990, when he was given a 60-year prison term for breaking into an Arkansas state trooper's home and stealing about $6,700-worth of items, including a gun.<ref name="Brunner1130"/><ref>{{Cite news|last=Robinson|first=Sean|title=Person of interest in slayings began criminal career as a teen |date=2009-11-29|work=[[The News Tribune]]|url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/topstories/story/973971.html|accessdate=2009-12-01}} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
During his sentencing on the charges, a circuit judge told Clemmons that he had broken his mother's heart, to which he responded, "I have broken my own heart."<ref name="ST1129"/> Clemmons was sentenced in 1989 to 35 years in prison for robbing the woman in front of the Little Rock hotel bar. Among his other sentences were six years for weapon possession based on his high school arrest;<ref name="Brunner1130"/> and eight years for burglary, theft and probation in Pulaski County on September 9, 1989. He was ineligible for parole until 2015 or later.<ref name="Brunner1130"/> He was originally held at the Tucker Correctional Facility in [[Tucker, Arkansas]],<ref>{{Citation|date=June 21, 1999|title=Executive Clemency Appeal|publication-place=[[Little Rock, Arkansas]] |publisher=Arkansas Board of Parole|page=1}}</ref> but was eventually transferred to the [[Cummins Unit]] near [[Grady, Arkansas|Grady]].<ref>{{Citation|date=July 13, 2000|title=Arkansas Post Prison Transfer Board Work Sheet |publication-place=[[Little Rock, Arkansas]]|publisher=Arkansas Board of Parole|page=1}}</ref>
==Clemency== {{Quote box |quoted=true |bgcolor=#FFFFF0 |salign=center |width=210px |align=right | quote = Where once stood a young ... misguided fool, who's {{sic}} own life he was unable to rule. Now stands a 27-year-old man, who has learned through 'the school of hard knocks' to appreciate and respect the rights of others. And who has in the midst of the harsh reality of prison life developed the necessary skills to stand along ([[sic]]) and not follow a multitude to do evil, as I did as a 16 year old child. | source = Maurice Clemmons, in his clemency application to Governor Mike Huckabee<ref name="Brunner1130"/>}} In 1999, after having served 10 years of his sentence, Clemmons filed a [[pardon|clemency]] appeal with Arkansas [[Governor of Arkansas|Governor]] [[Mike Huckabee]].<ref name="Robinson1201"/>
In his petition to Huckabee, Clemmons wrote he came from "a very good [[Christianity|Christian]] family" and was "raised much better than my actions speak".<ref name="Brunner1130"/><ref name="Murphy1201">{{Cite news|last=Murphy|first=Kim|title=Suspect in Seattle-area police slayings is shot and killed |work=[[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=2009-12-01|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nation-and-world/la-na-police-shooting2-2009dec02,0,7940378.story|accessdate=2009-12-01}}</ref> Clemmons claimed he had just moved from [[Seattle]], Washington, to Arkansas as a teenager, and because he had no friends he gave in to peer pressure and "fell in with the wrong crowd" to be accepted by his young peers, which led him to commit his crimes.<ref name="Brunner1130"/><ref name="Robinson1201"/> Although he apologized for his actions, Clemmons also complained that he received overly harsh sentences. He also claimed to have changed and expressed regret that his mother had recently died without seeing him turn his life around. Clemmons' clemency application was supported by Pulaski County Circuit Court Judge Marion Humphrey, who argued the cumulative sentence was excessive and cited Clemmons' young age at the time he committed the crimes.<ref name="Brunner1130"/>
The decision was made over the objections of some victims and prosecutors involved in Clemmons' previous cases but was supported by the bipartisan parole board and the trial court judge in Clemmons' case.<ref name="ST1129"/><ref name="Brunner1130"/><ref name="Robinson1201"/><ref name="Egan1130">{{Cite news|last=Egan|first=Timothy|author-link=Timothy Egan|date=2009-11-30|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Mike Huckabee's Burden|url=http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/11/30/mike-huckabees-burden/ |accessdate=2009-12-01}}</ref> Mark Fraiser, an attorney who prosecuted early cases against Clemmons in Pulaski County, argued Clemmons was extremely likely to commit further acts of violence in the future, and said for a teen to receive such a lengthy prison sentence without committing a murder, "you've got to be a bad little dude".<ref name="Brunner1130"/> On May 3, 2000, Huckabee commuted Clemmons' 108-year sentence to 47 years, 5 months and 19 days, which made him eligible for parole that day.<ref name="Brantley1130"/> As a factor in his decision, Huckabee cited the unusually long sentence for Clemmons' age at the time the crimes were committed.<ref name="ST1129"/> The Arkansas Parole Board unanimously approved Clemmons' release on July 13, 2000, and he was set free on August 1, 2000.<ref name="Brantley1130"/><ref name="Brunner1130"/>
==Later crimes== In March 2001, Clemmons violated parole by committing aggravated robbery and theft again in [[Ouachita County, Arkansas|Ouachita County]]. He was convicted on July 13, 2001 and sentenced to 10 years in prison.<ref name="Brantley1130"/> He faced charges of parole violations, but due to problems with the case, he was not served with the charges until 2004. His attorney argued the parole violation charges should be dropped because so much time had passed, and they were subsequently dismissed.<ref name="Robinson1201"/> Clemmons was granted parole on the robbery charges in 2004. He told the parole board he was "not ready" the first time he was released, but that he "doesn't want to die in prison" and will "try to do the right thing".<ref name="Murphy1201"/> Clemmons moved to Washington in 2004 while still on parole, which was approved by Arkansas authorities.<ref name="Brunner1130"/> That year, he married a woman named Nicole Smith, although ''[[The Seattle Times]]'' later reported the relationship had "been tumultuous".<ref name="ST1129"/><ref name="Brunner1130"/><ref name="Perry1201">{{Cite news|last1=Perry |first1=Nick |last2=O'Hagan |first2=Maureen |last3=Armstrong |first3=Ken |title=Four days in May set stage for Sunday's tragedy |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |date=2009-12-01 |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010392869_shootingjustice01m.html |accessdate=2009-12-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091204124641/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010392869_shootingjustice01m.html |archivedate=2009-12-04 |df= }}</ref> He was placed under the supervision of the [[Washington State Department of Corrections]] and classified as "high risk to reoffend". His supervision was to continue until October 2015. He lived in [[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma]], where he ran a landscaping and power-washing business out of his house.<ref name="ST1129"/> Over the next five years, Clemmons bought six houses, including one in Arkansas and five in Washington.<ref name="Robinson1201"/>
Following his parole in 2004, Clemmons had no arrests or problems with the law until May 2009.<ref name="Robinson1201"/> ''The Seattle Times'' referred to four days in May 2009 as the time when "Maurice Clemmons' behavior and mental state deteriorated".<ref name="Perry1201"/> On May 9, a [[Pierce County, Washington|Pierce County]] sheriff's deputy responded to Clemmons' home after reports he was throwing rocks at houses, cars and people. When the deputy tried to enter the house, one of Clemmons' cousins grabbed his wrist. After a struggle, Clemmons emerged from the house and punched the deputy in the face, and assaulted a second deputy who arrived to help. Clemmons was placed under arrest and taken to Pierce County Jail, where he continued to struggle and told jail workers, "I'll kill all you bitches."<ref name="Robinson1201"/><ref name="Perry1201"/> He was charged with two felony assault charges and two felony malicious mischief charges, and released from jail the next day after posting a $40,000 bail bond without seeing a judge.<ref name="Perry1201"/>
On May 11, around 1 a.m., Clemmons appeared naked in his living room and ordered two female relatives, ages 11 and 12, to fondle him. The two reportedly complied out of fear, and the 11-year-old fled the house afterward. Clemmons took the 12-year-old into his bedroom along with Clemmons' wife.<ref name="Perry1201"/> Clemmons repeatedly referred to himself as Jesus, and said his wife was [[Eve]].<ref name="Murphy1201"/><ref name="Perry1201"/> He released the 12-year-old girl after his wife begged him to let her go. However, around 4 a.m. that same morning, he gathered his family back into the living room and demanded they strip naked together. He later left the house, claiming the world was coming to an end and that he was "going to fly to [[heaven]]". A family member called 911 and police found Clemmons at a nearby second house he was building, but Clemmons fled on foot and escaped. He failed to appear the next day for an arraignment on his May 9 charges. [[Child Protective Services]] investigated and substantiated the [[sexual abuse]] complaint.<ref name="Perry1201"/> Latanya Clemmons, Clemmons's sister, told authorities he had undergone a change and was "not in his right mind".<ref name="Murphy1201"/>
Clemmons was arrested on July 1, 2009, after he appeared in a Pierce County court trying to have his [[bench warrant]] thrown out. He was charged with second-degree rape of a child, as well as being a fugitive from Arkansas.<ref name="Perry1201"/> At the time of his arrest, Clemmons made religiously themed comments and referred to himself as "the beast". He also told a police officer that [[United States president|President]] [[Barack Obama]] and [[LeBron James]] were his brothers, and [[Oprah Winfrey]] was his sister.<ref name="Robinson1201"/> Pierce County prosecutors asserted that Clemmons' recent crimes amounted to a violation of Clemmons' parole in Arkansas, and that he faced years in prison if he was returned to the state. However, the [[List of law enforcement agencies in Arkansas|Arkansas Department of Community Correction]] notified Pierce County on July 22 that they did not intend to ask for his [[extradition]] and that he should be [[adjudication|adjudicated]] on his Washington charges. Stephen Penner, a deputy prosecuting attorney in Pierce County, said of the Arkansas decision, "There's a built-in incentive to not following through. In a way, the more violent they are, the less you want them in your community."<ref name="Perry1201"/>
During a court-ordered mental health evaluation, Clemmons told psychologists he had experienced hallucinations in May 2009 of "people drinking blood and people eating babies, and lawless on the streets, like people were [[cannibalism|cannibals]]".<ref name="Robinson1201"/> He claimed the visions had since passed. He also claimed to have no faith in the American justice system and thought he was being "maliciously persecuted because I'm black and they believe the police".<ref name="Robinson1201"/> The evaluation, completed by two psychologists from the [[Western State Hospital (Washington State)|Western State Hospital]] on October 19, concluded Clemmons was dangerous and presented an increased risk of future criminal acts.<ref name="Robinson1201"/> Pierce County Judge John McCarthy set bail for Clemmons' assault charges at $40,000, considerably below the $100,000 prosecutors sought based on Clemmons' history of violence. Pierce County Judge Thomas Felnagle set bail for the child-rape charges at $150,000, lower than the $200,000 sought by prosecutors,<ref name="Perry1201"/> but higher than usual for the charges.<ref name="Brunner1130"/><ref name="Robinson1201"/>
After a mental evaluation, a psychologist concluded Clemmons was competent to stand trial on the charges, which eliminated him as a candidate for involuntary commitment. An attorney for Clemmons notified the court he planned to pursue an [[insanity defense|insanity]] or [[Diminished responsibility|diminished-capacity defense]].<ref name="ST1129"/><ref name="Robinson1201"/> On November 23, 2009, Clemmons paid $15,000 for a $190,000 bail bond from Jail Sucks Bail Bonds, a [[Chehalis, Washington|Chehalis]]-based company, to secure his release.<ref name="ST1129"/><ref name="Perry1201"/> Two other bail bond agencies had rejected Clemmons based on his history of failing to appear in court.<ref name="Perry1201"/>
==2009 shooting of police officers== {{Main|2009 Lakewood shooting}} [[Image:Pierce County Washington Incorporated and Unincorporated areas Lakewood Highlighted.svg|right|thumb|220 px|The location of [[Lakewood, Washington|Lakewood]] in [[Pierce County, Washington]], where Clemmons allegedly shot four police officers.]] Clemmons failed to check in with his community corrections officer within 24 hours of his release as required, but nothing was done in response.<ref name="MartinArmstrong">{{Cite news|last1=Martin |first1=Jonathan |last2=Armstrong |first2=Ken |title=Maurice Clemmons eyed police station as a target, too |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |date=October 21, 2010 |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2013170137_otherside21.html |accessdate=October 22, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101021234307/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2013170137_otherside21.html |archivedate=October 21, 2010 |df= }}</ref> On November 26, 2009, less than one week after Clemmons posted his bail bond,<ref name="ST1129"/><ref name="Egan1130"/> during a [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]] gathering at the home of Clemmons' aunt, Clemmons told several people he was angry about his Pierce County legal problems and that he planned to use a gun to murder police officers and others, including school children. He showed a gun to the people in the room and told them he had two others in his car and home. Clemmons said he planned to activate an alarm by removing a court-ordered [[ankle monitor]], then he would shoot the police officers who responded to his house.<ref name="Lynn0303">{{Cite news|last=Lynn|first=Adam|title=Prosecutors say Allen knew of Clemmons' plan|work=[[The News Tribune]]|date=March 3, 2010|url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/2010/03/03/1093806/preosecutors-say-allen-knew-of.html|accessdate=March 8, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name="SPI0302">{{Cite news|title=Alleged getaway driver in officer slayings charged with murder |date=March 2, 2010 |work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |url=http://www2.seattlepi.com/articles/416095.html |accessdate=March 8, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160129203627/http://www2.seattlepi.com/articles/416095.html |archivedate=January 29, 2016 |df= }}</ref> In describing the planned murder, Clemmons said, "Knock, knock, knock, boom!"<ref name="Lynn0303"/>
Darcus Allen, a convicted murderer who previously served in an Arkansas prison with Clemmons, was allegedly present for the conversation.<ref name="Lynn0303"/> Also on Thanksgiving, Clemmons cut off a GPS monitor which Jail Sucks Bail Bonds had secured onto his ankle.<ref name="MartinArmstrong"/> On November 28, Clemmons showed two handguns to friends Eddie and Douglas Davis and told them he planned to shoot police officers with them; the exchange was witnessed by Clemmons' half-brother Rickey Hinton, with whom he shared a house.<ref name="Netter1202"/> During the exchange, Clemmons danced around with the guns in his hands, claiming to be [[Lucifer]]. He told the men he had twice tried to go to a Tacoma police station, where he planned to walk in and start shooting. The first time the station was closed, and the second time he got a flat tire on the way there, Clemmons claimed. He talked about stopping at a crowded intersection or a school and shooting people there.<ref name="MartinArmstrong"/>
On the morning of November 29, Clemmons drove a white pickup truck to Allen's home, and then Allen drove him past the Forza Coffee Co. coffee shop in [[Parkland, Washington]], a suburb of [[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma]]. After they saw marked police patrol cars in the parking lot, Allen drove back past the coffee shop and parked nearby. Some reports from witnesses said Clemmons parked his truck in a car wash north of the coffee shop and pretended to clean the vehicle, but never turned the hose on.<ref name="Lynn0303" /><ref name="SPI0302" /> Around 8 a.m, Clemmons walked into the Forza Coffee Co. coffee shop, where four police officers were working on laptops before their shift. Clemmons opened fire on the officers, shooting them to death.<ref name="Murphy1201" /><ref name='seattletimes11291'>{{cite news|author=Miletich, Steve |author2=Sara Jean Green |authorlink= |title=Four police officers shot to death in Lakewood in apparent ambush |date=2009-11-29 |publisher= |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010382767_webfourdead29m.html |work=[[Seattle Times]] |accessdate=2009-11-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091202064239/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010382767_webfourdead29m.html |archivedate=2009-12-02 |df= }}</ref>
Investigators said the murders were a targeted, execution-style attack and not associated with a robbery;<ref name='vancouversun1129'>{{cite news|title=Shooting of four Lakewood officers 'an execution': Washington police |date=2009-11-29 |publisher=''[[Vancouver Sun]]'' |url=https://vancouversun.com/news/Four+Washington+police+officers+shot+dead+coffee+shop+ambush/2282821/story.html |accessdate=2009-11-29 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091202071108/http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Four%2BWashington%2Bpolice%2Bofficers%2Bshot%2Bdead%2Bcoffee%2Bshop%2Bambush/2282821/story.html |archivedate=2009-12-02 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Clemmons did not aim at any other customers or the two baristas working at the time.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Valdes|first=Manuel|title=Hundreds line up as Wash. coffee shop reopens|work=[[Associated Press]]|date=2009-12-12}}</ref> The four slain officers were Mark Renninger, 39 (killed with a shot to the head); Ronald Owens, 37 (shot in the neck); Tina Griswold, 40 (shot in the head); and Greg Richards, 42 (shot in the head).<ref name="Buck1130">{{Cite news|last=Buck |first=Michael|title=Slain cop a Valley native|work=[[The Express-Times]]|date=2009-11-30|page=A1}}</ref>
As Clemmons fled, Officer Richards struggled with him in the restaurant's doorway, then shot Clemmons in the back before the officer succumbed to a bullet wound to his head.<ref name="Murphy1201"/><ref name="Netter1202" /> The shooter stole Richards' [[Glock]] pistols before escaping.<ref name="MartinArmstrong"/> Clemmons returned to the truck and Allen drove him away. Allen later told detectives he stopped at an intersection and abandoned Clemmons and the truck, claiming he "wants no part of this". Authorities however, later disputed this claim and said there was no evidence Allen abandoned the vehicle.<ref name="Lynn0303"/><ref name="SPI0302"/> Clemmons was identified later that day as a "person of interest" in the murders,<ref name="Buck1130"/> but soon after was identified as a wanted suspect. Police identified no motive for the murders, and Detective Ed Troyer, Pierce County Sheriff’s Office spokesman, said, "We're going to be surprised if there is a motive worth mentioning."<ref name="Naughton1130">{{Cite news|last=Naughton|first=Philippe|work=[[The Times]]|date=2009-11-30|title=Police killing suspect Maurice Clemmons "has been shot"|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article6937729.ece|accessdate=2009-11-30}}</ref> Police initially believed the suspect might have died from his injuries shortly after the shooting.<ref name="Naughton1130"/><ref name="Pulkkinen1130">{{Cite news|last1=Pulkkinen|first1=Levi|last2=McNerthney|first2=Casey|last3=Ho|first3=Vanessa|title=Wounded suspect in officers' slaying on the run|work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|date=2009-11-30|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/412727_shooting29.html|accessdate=2009-11-30}}</ref>
Clemmons went back to his house and told Hinton he had been shot by police, and Hinton allegedly gave Eddie and Douglas Davis a car to "get Clemmons out of here". As they drove, Clemmons told the brothers he "had taken care of his business". The Davis brothers took Clemmons to other friends, who bandaged his wounds.<ref name="Netter1202"/> Later that day, police received a tip that Clemmons was seeking shelter from friends in [[Seattle]]. Police pulled over a white car they believed to have been transporting him, and the female driver admitted Clemmons was a friend and she had brought him to Seattle after he told her "he had killed a police officer or officers".<ref name="Netter1202"/>
Coffee shop employees who witnessed the shooting identified Clemmons as the shooter from a series of photos.<ref name="Netter1202"/> Authorities sought him in what was considered one of the biggest manhunts the Seattle-Tacoma area had ever seen, and Clemmons was considered the most wanted man in the Pacific Northwest.<ref name="Johnson1201">{{Cite news|last=Johnson|first=Gene |title=Seattle police kill suspect in officer slayings|work=[[Associated Press]]|date=2009-12-01}}</ref> Authorities also surrounded the homes of Clemmons' friends and family in order to prevent him from finding shelter, and to determine who was helping him.<ref name="Murphy1201"/><ref name="Netter1202"/> A relative learned that Clemmons was coming to her home in the [[Leschi, Seattle|Leschi]] neighborhood in Seattle, informed the police and fled. Police locked down the house for 11 hours in the early morning of November 30, believing Clemmons to be holed up inside. After several attempts to coax or force him out of the house, including use of a robot and flashbang grenades, police entered and discovered Clemmons was not inside.<ref name="Netter1202" /><ref name="Pulkkinen1130"/><ref>{{Cite news|last1=Karlinsky|first1=Neal|last2=Netter|first2=Sarah|title=Washington Cop Shooting Suspect Maurice Clemmons Not in House Targeted by Police|work=[[ABC News]]|date=2009-11-30|url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/GMA/police-target-lakewood-cop-shooting-suspect-maurice-clemmons/story?id=9202384|accessdate=2009-11-30}}</ref> Later that day, police searched multiple locations in the Seattle and Tacoma areas, including a park where they found a handgun carried by Clemmons and his pickup truck, which had blood stains inside.<ref name="Sullivan1201">{{Cite news|last1=Sullivan |first1=Jennifer |last2=Rahner |first2=Mark |last3=Broom |first3=Jack |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |date=2009-12-01 |title=Lakewood police shooting suspect killed by Seattle police officer in South Seattle early this morning |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010393433_webarrest01m.html |accessdate=2009-12-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091204124651/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010393433_webarrest01m.html |archivedate=2009-12-04 |df= }}</ref>
==Death== [[Image:Maurice Clemmons.jpeg|right|thumb|220 px|Post-shooting photograph of Clemmons with previous bullet wound visible.]] On December 1, 2009, Clemmons was shot and killed by [[Seattle Police Department|Seattle police]] officer Benjamin L. Kelly.<ref name="Gene1202">{{Cite news |last=Johnson |first=Gene |title=More charges likely in Wash. police killing |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=2009-12-02 |url=http://www.rrdailyherald.com/articles/2009/12/02/news/news_updates/doc4b16b47addf2f208706196.txt |accessdate=2009-12-21}}</ref><ref name="CBS1202">{{Cite news |title=Maurice Clemmons Manhunt: An Inside Look |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=2009-12-02 |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/12/02/national/main5862369.shtml |accessdate=2009-12-02}}</ref><ref name='clemmonsdead121'>{{cite news|last=Johnson |first=Gene |title=Seattle police kill suspect in officer slayings |date=2009-12-01 |work=[[Associated Press]]}}</ref><ref name="Miletich1202">{{Cite news|last1=Miletich |first1=Steve |last2=Broom |first2=Jack |title=Routine stolen-car check led to Lakewood police-slaying suspect |date=2009-12-02 |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010400199_shootingmainbar02m.html |accessdate=2009-12-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091204011100/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/localnews/2010400199_shootingmainbar02m.html |archivedate=2009-12-04 |df= }}</ref><ref name="McNerthney">{{Cite news |last1=McNerthney |first1=Casey |last2=Fears |first2=Shannon |title=Suspected cop killer slain by police |work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |date=2009-12-01 |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/412772_suspect01.html |accessdate=2009-12-02}}</ref> Around 2:45 a.m., Kelly was on patrol and stopped to investigate a broken-down car on the side of the road, which was idling with its hood up. Kelly recognized the vehicle as having been reported stolen. While sitting in his patrol car and writing a report, Kelly noticed Clemmons approaching him and recognized him as the suspect in the Lakewood shooting. Kelly ordered him to stop and show his hands, but he instead began to flee around the disabled vehicle.<ref name="Murphy1201" /><ref name="Netter1202" /><ref name="Johnson1201" /><ref name="Sullivan1201" /> Police claim that Clemmons reached into his waist area for a gun. Kelly fired several rounds at Clemmons and hit him at least twice, killing him.<ref name="Netter1202" /><ref name="Johnson1201" /><ref name="Gene1202" /><ref name="Miletich1202" /> Clemmons was carrying a handgun that had belonged to Lakewood Officer Greg Richards. Kelly was placed on routine administrative leave following the shooting.<ref name="Sullivan1201" /> Police later said Clemmons would have eventually died from the gunshot wound he sustained at the Lakewood shooting.<ref name="clemmonsdead121" />
Since his death, multiple people have been arrested for helping Clemmons during and after the Lakewood shooting. Authorities claim the accomplices misled police about his whereabouts, gave him cell phones and money, applied first aid to his gunshot wounds and tried to help him leave the state.<ref name="Murphy1201" /><ref name="Sullivan1201" /><ref name="Gene1202" /> Among those arrested were Clemmons' sister, who bandaged his wounds and provided him transportation.<ref name="Gene1202" /><ref name="CBS1202" /> Authorities arrested five other people for assisting Clemmons: Letricia Nelson, Quiana Williams, Douglas Davis, Eddie Davis, and Ricky Hinton.<ref name="Netter1202">{{Cite news |last=Netter |first=Sarah |title=Helping a Cop Killer: Maurice Clemmons' Friends, Family Busted |date=2009-12-02 |work=[[ABC News]] |url=http://abcnews.go.com/WN/US/hunting-washington-cop-killer-maurice-clemmons/story?id=9226301 |accessdate=2009-12-20}}</ref> Darcus Allen was arrested and charged with aggravated first-degree murder for his alleged role as Clemmons' getaway driver. Allen claims he did not know Clemmons' plans when he drove him to the coffee shop, but authorities argued he had known for days that Clemmons planned to murder police officers.<ref name="Lynn0303" /><ref name="SPI0302" />
Funeral arrangements were kept private by the family due to the circumstances of his crime.<ref name="STimes1206" />

always enter the religion first --> | denomination = | awards = <!--Military service--> | nickname = | allegiance = United Kingdom | branch = [[Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve]] | serviceyears = 1942–1946 | rank = [[Flight lieutenant]] | unit = [[RAF Medical Services]] | commands = | battles = [[World War II]] | mawards = }} '''George Morrison 'Morris' Carstairs''', {{Post-nominals|country=GBR|FRCPE|FRCPsych|size=100%|sep=,}} (18 June 1916 – 17 April 1991) was a British [[psychiatrist]], [[anthropologist]], and academic. He was Professor of Psychological Medicine at the [[University of Edinburgh]] from 1961 to 1973, President of the [[World Federation for Mental Health|World Mental Health Organization]] from 1968 to 1972, and Vice-Chancellor of the [[University of York]] from 1973 to 1978.<ref name="Oxford DNB">{{cite web|last1=Rollin|first1=Henry R.|title=Carstairs, George Morrison (1916–1991)|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/49602|website=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=1 October 2014|doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/49602|year=2004}}</ref><ref name="obit - Times">{{cite news|title=Prof Morris Carstairs; Obituary|work=The Times|date=2 May 1991}}</ref> In his youth, he had been a distinguished long-distance runner.<ref name="obit - British Journal of Sports Medicine">{{cite journal|title=Professor G. M. Carstairs MD, FRCPEd, FRCPsych|journal=British Journal of Sports Medicine|year=1991|volume=25|issue=3|page=116|doi=10.1136/bjsm.25.3.116|url=http://bjsportmed.com/content/25/3/116.full.pdf|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref><ref name="letter - Times">{{cite news|last1=MacLeod|first1=John|title=Dr Morris Carstairs; Obituary|work=The Times|date=1 July 1991}}</ref>
==Early life== Carstairs was born on 18 June 1916 in [[Mussoorie]], [[India]], then part of the [[British Raj]].<ref name="obit - British Journal of Sports Medicine" /><ref name="bio - Anent Scottish Running">{{cite web|title=GM Carstairs|url=http://www.anentscottishrunning.com/gm-carstairs/|publisher=Anent Scottish Running|date=5 January 2014|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref> He was the son of the Reverend Dr George Carstairs, a [[Church of Scotland]] missionary, and Elizabeth Huntley Carstairs (née Young).<ref name="Oxford DNB" /> He spent his childhood living in India and became fluent in both English and Hindi.<ref name="Oxford DNB" /><ref name="obit - British Journal of Sports Medicine" /> At the age of ten, he and his family moved to [[Edinburgh]], Scotland. He was educated at [[George Watson's College]], then an all-boys [[Independent school (United Kingdom)|independent school]] in Edinburgh.<ref name="Oxford DNB" /> He went on to study medicine at the [[University of Edinburgh]]. In 1941, he graduated [[Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery]] (MB ChB).<ref name="obit - British Journal of Sports Medicine" />
He was an accomplished [[Long-distance running|long-distance runner]] in his youth. He was the Scottish 3 miles champion in 1937, 1938 and 1939.<ref name="obit - British Journal of Sports Medicine" /> He represented Scotland at the [[1937 International University Games]], winning a silver medal in the [[5000 metres]] in a time of 15:24.2. He also represented Scotland at the [[1939 International University Games]], winning a gold medal in the 5000 metres in a time of 15:20.2.<ref>{{cite web|title=WORLD STUDENT GAMES (PRE-UNIVERSIADE)|url=http://www.gbrathletics.com/ic/wsg.htm|website=GBR Athletics|accessdate=1 October 2014}}</ref> He represented Great Britain at the [[1938 European Athletics Championships]], coming sixth in the [[1938 European Athletics Championships – Men's 5000 metres|Men's 5000 metres]] with a time of 14:51.3.<ref name="obit - British Journal of Sports Medicine" />
==Career==
===Military service=== Having completed medical training, Carstairs was called up for active service during [[World War II]] as a medical officer with the [[Royal Air Force]].<ref name="Oxford DNB" /> He was commissioned into the Medical Branch of the [[Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve]] on 15 May 1942 as a [[flying officer]] (emergency).<ref name="LG 16 June 1942">{{London Gazette |issue=35598 |date=16 June 1942 |page=2663 }}</ref> He was promoted to [[flight lieutenant]] ([[war substantive]]) on 15 May 1943.<ref name="LG 27 July 1943">{{London Gazette |issue=36113 |date=27 July 1943 |page=3451 |supp=y }}</ref> He was demobilised in 1946.<ref name="Oxford DNB" />
===Medical career=== Following graduation in 1941, Carstairs worked in [[general medicine]]. He was an assistant physician at the [[Royal Edinburgh Hospital]] for a year.<ref name="Oxford DNB" /> He served as a medical officer with the [[Royal Air Force]] between 1942 and 1946.<ref name="obit - British Journal of Sports Medicine" />
In 1953, he began his career in [[psychiatry]] when he was appointed a [[senior registrar]] at the [[Maudsley Hospital]], a [[psychiatric hospital]] in London, England.<ref name="Oxford DNB" /> There he worked with chronic psychiatric patients under the supervision of [[Aubrey Lewis|Sir Aubrey Lewis]].<ref name="Oxford DNB" /><ref name="obit - Times" /> During his work, he come to the conclusion that patients with [[schizophrenia]] needed a neutral environment to cope with their condition and returning them to an 'emotionally charged family setting' would only set back their recovery.<ref name="obit - British Journal of Sports Medicine" /> He also discovered that improved motivation in patients helped their rehabilitation.<ref name="letter - Times" />
In 1960, he was appointed head of a new [[Medical Research Council (United Kingdom)|Medical Research Council]] unit based at [[University College London]]. This unit led the study of [[psychiatric epidemiology]] in the United Kingdom.<ref name="Oxford DNB" /> When he moved to Edinburgh in 1961, he moved the unit with him and continued its research. He stood down as director in 1971, and was followed by [[Norman Kreitman]].<ref name="obit - British Journal of Sports Medicine" />
From 1968 to 1972, he was President of the [[World Federation for Mental Health|World Mental Health Organization]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Past Presidents|url=http://wfmh.com/about/past-presidents/|publisher=World Federation for Mental Health|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref> While holding that post, he was involved in the development of psychiatric facilities in under-developed countries.<ref name="Oxford DNB" /> In 1978, he left academia and devoted his time to advising the [[World Health Organization]] on developing psychiatric services in India, with emphasis on making them appropriate to Asian needs.<ref name="obit - Times" />
===Academic career=== In 1961, Carstairs was appointed Professor of Psychological Medicine at the [[University of Edinburgh]]. At the university he created a new working group of academics and practising psychiatrists for research and teaching; it was the first such group created outside London.<ref name="obit - British Journal of Sports Medicine" /> At the university he taught a wide range of course at both undergraduate and graduate level.<ref name="Oxford DNB" />
He gave the 1962 [[Reith Lectures]], a renowned public lecture series broadcast on [[BBC Radio]], titled ''This Island Now''.<ref name="obit - British Journal of Sports Medicine" /><ref name="BBC - Reith Lectures">{{cite web|title=George Carstairs: This Island Now: 1962|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p00h9l9f|website=The Reith Lectures|publisher=BBC|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref> In one lecture he condoned [[pre-marital sex]], which produced controversy.<ref name="obit - Times" /> His statement of belief was offensive to many British Christians, particularly given that he was the son of a clergyman.<ref name="Oxford DNB" />
In January 1973, he was appointed Vice-Chancellor of the [[University of York]]. He was only the second person to head the university as it had only been established in 1963.<ref name="bio - York">{{cite web|title=Dr Morris Carstairs|url=https://www.york.ac.uk/records-management/archive/history/vcs/#tab-2|website=Vice-Chancellors|publisher=University of York|accessdate=31 October 2014}}</ref> The 1970s were a difficult time to be involved in university leadership in the United Kingdom. The country was [[Early 1980s recession#Recession in the United Kingdom|in recession]] and [[student protests]] were frequent.<ref name="obit - Times" /> He had plans to expand the university both physically and in the number of subjects it taught, but because of the hostile atmosphere he faced these were not achieved during his vice-chancellorship.<ref name="bio - York" /> This experience meant that he never returned to full-time academia after leaving the post in the summer of 1978.<ref name="obit - Times" /><ref name="bio - York" />
==Later life== Carstairs suffered from [[senile dementia]] in his later years.<ref name="Oxford DNB" /> He withdrew from professional life, and was cared for by his first wife.<ref name="obit - Times" /> He died at his Edinburgh home on 17 April 1991.<ref name="Oxford DNB" />
