[[University of Law]] |website = {{Official website|http://www.sadiq.london/}} }} '''Sadiq Aman Khan''' ({{IPAc-en|s|ə|ˈ|d|iː|k|_|ˈ|k|ɑː|n}}; born 8 October 1970) is a British politician serving as [[Mayor of London]] since 2016. He was the [[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Tooting (UK Parliament constituency)|Tooting]] from 2005 to 2016. A member of the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] and its regional [[London Labour Party]], he is on the party's [[soft left]] wing and has been ideologically characterised as a [[Social democracy|social democrat]]. Born in [[Tooting]], [[South London]], to a working-class [[British Pakistani]] family, Khan earned a [[law degree]] from the [[University of North London]]. He subsequently worked as a solicitor specialising in human rights, and chaired [[Liberty (advocacy group)|Liberty]] for three years. Joining the Labour Party, Khan was a [[Councillor]] for the [[London Borough of Wandsworth]] from 1994 to 2006 before being elected as Member of Parliament for Tooting at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 general election]]. Under the Labour government of Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]], Khan was appointed [[Department for Communities and Local Government|Minister of State for Communities]] in 2008, later becoming [[Minister of State for Transport]]. A key ally of former Labour leader [[Ed Miliband]], he served in the [[Shadow Cabinet of Ed Miliband|Miliband's Shadow Cabinet]] as [[Shadow Secretary of State for Justice]], [[Shadow Lord Chancellor]], and [[Minister for London|Shadow Minister for London]]. Khan was elected Mayor of London at the [[London mayoral election, 2016|May 2016 mayoral election]], succeeding [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] mayor [[Boris Johnson]]. He immediately resigned as MP for [[Tooting (UK Parliament constituency)|Tooting]] upon his victory at the mayoral election. He is London's first [[ethnic minority]] mayor. Khan won the largest number of votes in one election of any politician in British history. As mayor, he has introduced reforms to limit charges on London's public transport, backed London Gatwick Airport expansion, and focused on uniting the city's varied communities. He was a vocal supporter of the unsuccessful [[Britain Stronger in Europe]] campaign to [[United Kingdom European Union membership referendum, 2016|retain UK membership]] of the [[European Union]]. He has been included in the [[Time 100|''Time'' 100]] list of world's most influential people.{{cite web|title=Sadiq Khan: The World’s 100 Most Influential People|url=http://time.com/collection/most-influential-people-2018/5217530/sadiq-khan/|website=[[Time 100|''Time'' 100]]|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''|year=2018|accessdate=22 April 2018|language=en-us}} ==Early life== Khan was born on 8 October 1970 at [[St George's Hospital]] in [[Tooting]], [[South London]] to a working-class [[Sunni Muslim]] family.{{cite web|last1=Eaton|first1=George|title=The pugilist: Sadiq Khan’s quest to become mayor of London|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/uk/2016/03/pugilist-sadiq-khan-s-quest-become-mayor-london|work=New Statesman|accessdate=11 March 2016|quote=His grandparents emigrated from India to [[Karachi]], [[Pakistan]] following Partition; his parents emigrated from Pakistan to London shortly before his birth.|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160312070742/http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/uk/2016/03/pugilist-sadiq-khan-s-quest-become-mayor-london|archivedate=12 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/31/sadiq-khan-aspiration-labour-leadership-overused-blair|title=Sadiq Khan says 'aspiration' will be Labour leadership race's most overused word|author=Rowena Mason and Simon Hattenstone|newspaper=The Observer|date=31 May 2015|accessdate=1 June 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150601002649/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/31/sadiq-khan-aspiration-labour-leadership-overused-blair|archivedate=1 June 2015|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://next.ft.com/content/8c974c8e-1379-11e6-bb40-c30e3bfcf63b|title=Victory for Sadiq Khan highlights tolerant face of London|work=[[Financial Times]]|date=7 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160626155723/https://next.ft.com/content/8c974c8e-1379-11e6-bb40-c30e3bfcf63b|archivedate=26 June 2016|df=dmy-all}} His grandparents migrated from [[Lucknow]] in [[United Provinces (1937–50)|United Provinces]], [[British India]] to [[Pakistan]] following the [[partition of India]] in 1947.{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/world/sadiq-khan-makes-historic-border-crossing-on-foot-from-india-to-pakistan-a3712026.html|title=Sadiq Khan makes historic border crossing from India to Pakistan on foot|work=[[London Evening Standard]]|date=6 December 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171207035206/https://www.standard.co.uk/news/world/sadiq-khan-makes-historic-border-crossing-on-foot-from-india-to-pakistan-a3712026.html|archivedate=7 December 2017|df=dmy-all}} His father Amanullah and mother Sehrun arrived in London from Pakistan in 1968.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=14}} Khan was the fifth of eight children, all but one of whom were boys.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=14}} In the city, Amanullah worked as a bus driver and Sehrun as a [[seamstress]].{{sfn|Hill|2016|pp=14–15}} [[File:ErnestBevinSchool.jpg|thumb|left|Ernest Bevin College in Tooting]] Khan and his siblings grew up in a three-bedroom [[council flat]] on the Henry Prince Estate in [[Earlsfield]].{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=15}} He attended Fircroft Primary School and then [[Ernest Bevin College|Ernest Bevin School]], a local [[comprehensive school|comprehensive]].{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=15}} Khan studied science and mathematics at [[A-level]], in the hope of eventually becoming a dentist. A teacher recommended that he read law instead, as he had an argumentative personality. The teacher's suggestion, along with the American television programme ''[[L.A. Law]]'', inspired Khan to do so. He read Law at the [[University of North London]] (now [[London Metropolitan University]]). His parents later moved out of their council flat and purchased their own home.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=15}} Like his brothers, Khan was a fan of sport, particularly enjoying football, cricket, and boxing.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=15}} From his earliest years, Khan worked: "I was surrounded by my mum and dad working all the time, so as soon as I could get a job, I got a job. I got a paper round, a Saturday job—some summers I laboured on a building site." The family continues to send money to relatives in Pakistan, "because we're blessed being in this country." He and his family often encountered racism..., which led to him and his brothers taking up boxing at the Earlsfield Amateur Boxing Club. While studying for his degree, between the ages of 18 and 21, he had a Saturday job at the [[Peter Jones (department store)|Peter Jones]] department store in [[Sloane Square]].{{cite web |last=Cooper |first=Goolistan |title=Sadiq Khan recounts life lessons learned working at Chelsea department store |date=1 February 2016 |website=GetWestLondon |url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/news/west-london-news/sadiq-khan-recounts-life-lessons-10811540 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602221552/http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/news/west-london-news/sadiq-khan-recounts-life-lessons-10811540 |archivedate=2 June 2016 |df=dmy-all }} ==Legal career== Before entering the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] in 2005, Khan practised as a solicitor. After completing his law degree in 1991, Khan took his [[Law Society]] [[Final examination|finals]] at the [[University of Law|College of Law]] in [[Guildford]].{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=16}}{{cite|url=http://www.politics.co.uk/reference/sadiq-aman-khan|title=Sadiq Khan, biography|website=www.politics.co.uk/|date=2015|access-date=25 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604043218/http://www.politics.co.uk/reference/sadiq-aman-khan|archivedate=4 June 2016|df=dmy-all}} In 1994 he married Saadiya Ahmed, who was also a solicitor.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=15}} In 1994 he became a trainee solicitor at a firm of solicitors called ''Christian Fisher''; the firm specialised in legal aid cases. The partners were Michael Fisher and [[Louise Christian]]. Khan became a partner in 1997, and like Christian, specialised in human rights law. When Fisher left in 2002, the firm was renamed ''Christian Khan''.{{cite|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/31/sadiq-khan-london-mayor-tony-blair-aspiration|publisher=The Guardian|title=Sadiq Khan: ‘Ruthless? No. Decency can get you to the top in politics’|access-date=25 May 2017|date=31 May 2015|first1=Simon|last1=Hattenstone|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170505182605/https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/may/31/sadiq-khan-london-mayor-tony-blair-aspiration|archivedate=5 May 2017|df=dmy-all}}{{cite|url=http://www.lag.org.uk/magazine/2015/12/claims-that-sadiq-khan’s-former-human-rights-firm-‘was-worth-millions’-queried-by-lawyers.aspx|title=Claims that Sadiq Khan’s former human rights firm ‘was worth millions’ queried by lawyers|publisher=Legal Action Group|last1=Bawdon|first1=Fiona|date=December 2015|work=Legal Action magazine|access-date=25 May 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180117214943/http://www.lag.org.uk/magazine/2015/12/claims-that-sadiq-khan%E2%80%99s-former-human-rights-firm-%E2%80%98was-worth-millions%E2%80%99-queried-by-lawyers.aspx|archivedate=17 January 2018|df=dmy-all}}{{cite|url=http://www.lag.org.uk/magazine/2015/05/dear-sadiq-khan-when-you-left-christian-khan-to-become-an-mp,-you-said-you-could-bring-about-more-change-as-a-politician-than-a-lawyer-what-happened.aspx|publisher=Legal Action Group|title=Dear Sadiq Khan. When you left Christian Khan to become an MP, you said you could bring about more change as a politician than a lawyer. August 2017|df=dmy-all}} ==Parliamentary career== ===First term: 2005–2010=== [[File:Sadiq Khan, September 2009 cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Sadiq Khan in 2009]] Before entering Parliament, Khan represented [[Tooting]] as a Councillor for the [[London Borough of Wandsworth]] from 1994 to 2006, and was granted the title of [[Title of honor|Honorary]] [[Alderman]] of [[Wandsworth]] upon his retirement from local politics.[http://www.politics.co.uk/reference/sadiq-aman-khan http://www.politics.co.uk/reference/sadiq-aman-khan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604043218/http://www.politics.co.uk/reference/sadiq-aman-khan |date=4 June 2016 }}, politics In 2003, [[Tooting (UK Parliament constituency)|Tooting]] [[Constituency Labour Party]] decided to open its parliamentary selection to all interested candidates, including the incumbent MP since 1974, [[Tom Cox (politician)|Tom Cox]]. This prompted Cox, then in his mid-70s, to announce his retirement rather than risk de-selection. In the subsequent selection contest, Khan defeated five other local candidates to become Labour's candidate for the seat. He was elected to [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2005|2005 general election]]. Khan was one of the Labour MPs who led the successful opposition to Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]]'s proposed introduction of 90 days' detention without charge for those suspected of terrorism offences.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=20}} In recognition of this, ''[[The Spectator]]''—a right-wing magazine then edited by [[Boris Johnson]]—awarded him the "Newcomer of the Year Award" at the 2005 Parliamentarian of the Year Awards.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=20}} The magazine's editorial board stated that he had received the award "for the tough-mindedness and clarity with which he has spoken about the very difficult issues of Islamic terror".{{cite news |url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/archive/features/14489/part_2/parliamentarian-of-the-year.thtml?SelectedIssueDate=19%20November%202005 |date=19 November 2005 |title=Parliamentarian of the Year |work=[[The Spectator]] |accessdate=27 March 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090616124012/http://www.spectator.co.uk/archive/features/14489/part_2/parliamentarian-of-the-year.thtml?SelectedIssueDate=19%20November%202005 |deadurl=yes |archivedate=16 June 2009 |df=dmy }} In August 2006, he was a signatory of an open letter to [[Tony Blair]] that was signed by prominent Muslims and published in ''[[The Guardian]]''. The letter criticised [[Foreign policy of the United Kingdom|UK foreign policy]] and in particular the 2003 invasion of Iraq, stating that Blair's policies had caused great harm to civilians in the Middle East and provided "ammunition to extremists who threaten us all".{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=27}}{{cite news|title=Minister criticises Muslim letter |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/4787119.stm |date=12 August 2006 |accessdate=27 March 2009 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |archivedate=8 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108143352/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/4787119.stm |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Khan had to repay £500 in [[United Kingdom parliamentary expenses scandal|expenses]] in 2007 in relation to a newsletter sent to constituents featuring a 'Labour rose', which was deemed to be unduly prominent. While the content of the newsletter was not deemed to be party political, the rose logo was found to be unduly prominent which may have had the effect of promoting a political party. There was no suggestion that Khan had deliberately or dishonestly compiled his [[Expense management|expenses claims]], which were not explicitly disallowed under the rules at that time. The rules were retrospectively changed disallowing the claim, which had previously been approved by the House of Commons authorities.{{cite web|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmselect/cmstnprv/182/182.pdf|title=Microsoft Word – Baker-Bruce-Khan – CRC Rep.doc|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|accessdate=7 June 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013064730/http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmselect/cmstnprv/182/182.pdf|archivedate=13 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/london/7142779.stm |title=Minister's rose emblem broke rule |publisher=BBC News |date=13 December 2007 |accessdate=15 December 2010 |deadurl=no |archivedate=17 October 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101017175350/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/london/7142779.stm |df=dmy }} On 3 February 2008, ''[[The Sunday Times]]''{{cite news|author=Michael Gillard|author2=Jonathan Calvert|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article3295393.ece|title=Police bugged Muslim MP Sadiq Khan|work=[[The Sunday Times]]|date=3 February 2008|location=London|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516004326/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article3295393.ece|archivedate=16 May 2008|df=dmy-all}} claimed that a conversation between Khan and prisoner [[Babar Ahmad]] – a constituent accused of involvement in terrorism – at [[Woodhill Prison]] in [[Milton Keynes]] had been [[bugging|bugged]] by the [[Metropolitan Police Anti-Terrorist Branch]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7224786.stm |title=Khan welcomes 'bugging' inquiry |publisher=BBC News |date=3 February 2008 |accessdate=7 June 2011 |archivedate=25 March 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090325035405/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7224786.stm |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} An inquiry was launched by the [[Secretary of State for Justice|Justice Secretary]], [[Jack Straw]]. There was concern that the bugging contravened the [[Wilson Doctrine]] that police should not bug MPs. The report concluded that the doctrine did not apply because it affected only bugging requiring approval by the Home Secretary, while in Khan's case the monitoring was authorised by a senior police officer. The Home Secretary, [[Jacqui Smith]], then announced a further policy review and said the bugging of discussions between MPs and their constituents should be banned.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/feb/22/uksecurity.police?gusrc=rss&feed=uknews |title=Bugging of MP on prison visit did not break the rules, inquiry finds |first=Vikram |last=Dodd |date=22 February 2008 |accessdate=4 July 2009 |location=London |newspaper=The Guardian |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140831203539/http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2008/feb/22/uksecurity.police?gusrc=rss&feed=uknews |archivedate=31 August 2014 |df=dmy }} In June 2007, Blair stood down as both Prime Minister and Labour Party leader, to be replaced by [[Gordon Brown]]. Brown thought highly of Khan, who moved up the parliamentary ranks under Brown's Premiership.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=27}} Brown made Khan a party whip, who was therefore charged with ensuring that Labour-sponsored legislation successfully made it through the parliamentary process to become law.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=27}} In July 2008, Khan helped push through a government proposal to permit the detention of those suspected of terror offenses for 42 days without charge.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=27}} For his part in this, Khan was criticised by Liberty's [[Shami Chakrabarti]] and others, who claimed that Khan had contravened his principles on civil liberties issues.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=27}} [[File:Rt Hon Sadiq Khan MP at Has Labour lost the plot on crime?.jpg|thumb|left|
Sadiq Khan speaking in 2011
]] On Prime Minister [[Gordon Brown]]'s [[Cabinet reshuffle]] of 3 October 2008, Khan was appointed [[Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State]] [[Department for Communities and Local Government|for Communities and Local Government]].{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=27}}{{cite|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081126155329/http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/corporate/pdf/707527.pdf|url=http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/corporate/pdf/707527.pdf|title=Ministerial Team|publisher=[[Department for Communities and Local Government]]|website=www.communities.gov.uk|archive-date=26 November 2008|dead-url=yes |df=dmy }}{{cite|url=https://www.theyworkforyou.com/mp/11878/sadiq_khan/tooting#profile|title=Sadiq Khan, Former MP, Tooting, profile|publisher=TheyWorkForYou|website=www.theyworkforyou.com|access-date=21 May 2017|df=dmy|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170525055553/https://www.theyworkforyou.com/mp/11878/sadiq_khan/tooting#profile|archivedate=25 May 2017}} In 2008, the [[Fabian Society]] published Khan's book, ''Fairness Not Favours''. Wolmar]], [[Gareth Thomas (English politician)|Gareth Thomas]], [[David Lammy]], and [[Tessa Jowell]].{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=35}} Jowell, who had been an MP for 23 years and had led London's successful nomination to host the [[2012 Olympic Games]], was widely regarded as the favourite to win by bookmakers and opinion polls.{{sfn|Hill|2016|pp=35–36}} Khan soon gained the support of prominent figures in the party, including former Mayor of London [[Ken Livingstone]], who was on Labour's leftist, socialist wing, and [[Oona King]], who was on its centrist, [[Blairism|Blairite]] wing.{{sfn|Hill|2016|pp=37–39}} He also received the backing of the Labour-affiliated [[GMB (trade union)|GMB]] and [[Unite the Union|Unite]] unions,{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=40}} and the nomination of 44 of Labour's 73 parliamentary constituent parties in London, leaving him as one of the top two contenders alongside Jowell.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=40}} Khan's main rival was Conservative candidate [[Zac Goldsmith]]; Khan described him as a spoiled dilettante who "never finishes anything he starts".{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=103}} A [[YouGov]] poll for [[LBC]] suggested that while Jowell would defeat Goldsmith in a Mayoral election, Khan would not.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=62}} In hustings, Khan placed an emphasis on his working-class origins, which would play against Jowell's wealthier upbringing, and argued for the need for change in London, thereby insinuating that Jowell would represent too much continuity with the outgoing Johnson administration.{{sfn|Hill|2016|pp=42–43}} In September 2015, Khan was announced as the winning nominee.{{sfn|Hill|2016|pp=73–74}} He gained 48,152 votes (58.9%) against Jowell's 35,573 (41.1%).{{sfn|Hill|2016|pp=73–74}}{{cite web|last1=Wintour|first1=Patrick|title=Sadiq Although he had previously backed Heathrow expansion, he now opposed it, instead calling for expansion at [[Gatwick Airport]]; he was likely aware that supporting the former was a vote loser in Britain]].{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=79}} Concerned that Corbyn's socialist platform was alienating many of London's businesses, Khan declared that he would be "the most pro-business mayor ever",{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=84}} and met with groups like the [[Federation of Small Businesses]] and [[City of London Corporation]].{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=109}} He also ensured that his campaign was run entirely separate from Corbyn.{{sfn|Hill|2016|pp=116–117}} [[File:London mayoral election by borough 2016 map.png|thumb|right|Map of Greater London boroughs that produced a majority for Khan (red) and |archivedate=8 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }} The journalist Dave Hill described Khan as a [[social liberalism|social liberal]],{{cite web |last=Hill |first=Dave |title=Sadiq Khan's first 100 days as London mayor: how is he doing? |date=16 August 2016 |website=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/aug/16/sadiq-khans-first-100-days-as-london-mayor-how-is-he-doing |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170221155635/https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/aug/16/sadiq-khans-first-100-days-as-london-mayor-how-is-he-doing |archivedate=21 February 2017 |df=dmy-all }} and Khan has self-described as a "proud feminist". Khan received death threats from Islamic extremists after voting in favour of the [[Marriage (Same Sex Couples) Act 2013|same-sex marriage equality bill]].{{cite web |url=http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2013/02/18/labour-mp-sadiq-khan-receives-death-threats-for-supporting-same-sex-marriage/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-04 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330023159/http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2013/02/18/labour-mp-sadiq-khan-receives-death-threats-for-supporting-same-sex-marriage/ |archivedate=30 March 2014 |df=dmy-all }}Jane Onyanga-Omara], [https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2016/05/06/sadiq-khan-london-mayor-muslim/84016822/ 5 things to know about London's first Muslim mayor] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116015859/http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2016/05/06/sadiq-khan-london-mayor-muslim/84016822/ |date=16 January 2017 }}, ''USA Today'' (May 6, 2017). He was also threatened by the far-right group [[Britain First]], which in 2016 threatened to take "[[direct action]]" against Khan where he "lives, works and prays" as part of an anti-Muslim campaign.Olivia Blair, [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/sadiq-khan-britain-first-london-mayor-threaten-direct-action-a7047991.html Britain First threatens to target London Mayor Sadiq Khan with 'direct action'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170912193411/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/sadiq-khan-britain-first-london-mayor-threaten-direct-action-a7047991.html |date=12 September 2017 }}, ''The Independent'' (May 25, 2016). ==Reception== In January 2013 and 2015, Khan was nominated for the Politician of the Year Award at the [[British Muslim Awards]].{{cite news|url=http://www.asianimage.co.uk/news/10197507.Winners_honoured_at_British_Muslim_Awards/|title=Winners honoured at British Muslim Awards|publisher=Asian Image|date=31 January 2013|accessdate=1 November 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151121173521/http://www.asianimage.co.uk/news/10197507.Winners_honoured_at_British_Muslim_Awards/|archivedate=21 November 2015|df=dmy-all}} He later won the award in February 2016.{{cite news|url=http://www.asianworldnews.co.uk/business/british-muslim-awards-2016/|title=British Muslim Awards 2016|publisher=Asian World|date=17 February 2016|accessdate=1 April 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160421220433/http://asianworldnews.co.uk/business/british-muslim-awards-2016/|archivedate=21 April 2016|df=dmy-all}} Not all British Muslims have however supported him; some of the supporters of [[Lutfur Rahman (politician)|Lutfur Rahman]]—whom Khan opposed—claimed that Khan was part of an Islamophobic Labour establishment.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=58}} Journalist Dave Hill has said that Khan was "savvy, streetwise and not averse to a scrap"{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=101}}, whilst also describing him as having a "joshing, livewire off-stage personality" which differed from the formal image he often projected while onstage.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=59}} Khan used to perform [[stand-up comedy]] before running for Mayor, including a ten-minute money-raising ''Stand Up for Labour'' routine. Comedian [[Arthur Smith (comedian)|Arthur Smith]] stated that Khan could become a "good club-level comedian one day".{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2016/09/05/25710/sadiq_khan%3A_i_used_to_do_stand-up|title=Sadiq Khan: 'I used to do stand-up'|work=Chortle|year=2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160927083831/http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2016/09/05/25710/sadiq_khan%3A_i_used_to_do_stand-up|archivedate=27 September 2016|df=dmy-all}} During the 2016 Mayoral campaign, Goldsmith referred to Khan as "a caricature machine politician... the sort of politician who justified peoples' mistrust in politics", as evidence citing Khan's U-turn on supporting Heathrow expansion.{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=116}} Another rival in the 2016 Mayoral campaign, [[George Galloway]] of the [[Respect Party]], referred to Khan as a "flip-flop merchant" and a "product of the Blairite machine".{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=139}} ==Personal life== Khan is a practising [[Muslim]],{{cite web|title=London elects its first Muslim mayor and the journalism world rightly notes its importance|url=http://www.getreligion.org/getreligion/2016/5/8/london-elects-a-muslim-mayor-and-the-journalism-world-rightly-notes-it-as-a-new-day|publisher=Getreligion.org|accessdate=14 May 2016|date=9 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160511121118/http://www.getreligion.org/getreligion/2016/5/8/london-elects-a-muslim-mayor-and-the-journalism-world-rightly-notes-it-as-a-new-day|archivedate=11 May 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|last1=Sherwood|first1=Harriet|title='This is our moment': Tooting Muslims laud Sadiq Khan victory|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/07/our-moment-tooting-muslims-sadiq-khan-london-mayoral-election-victory|accessdate=14 May 2016|work=The Guardian|date=7 May 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160512035232/http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/may/07/our-moment-tooting-muslims-sadiq-khan-london-mayoral-election-victory|archivedate=12 May 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=Sadiq hosts Eid celebrations|url=http://www.sadiqkhan.org.uk/sadiq_hosts_eid_celebrations|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160609203340/http://www.sadiqkhan.org.uk/sadiq_hosts_eid_celebrations|publisher=sadiqkhan.org.uk|archive-date=9 June 2016|accessdate=14 May 2016}} who observes the fast during [[Ramadan]],{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=58}} and regularly attends Al-Muzzammil Mosque in Tooting. Writing in ''[[The Guardian]]'', the journalist Dave Hill described Khan as "a moderate, socially liberal Muslim". He has expressed the view that "too often the people who are 'representing' the Islamic faith aren't representative, they're angry men with beards. And that is not what Islam is about."{{sfn|Hill|2016|p=83}} Khan married Saadiya Ahmed, a fellow solicitor, in 1994. They have two daughters, both raised in the Islamic faith.{{Cite news |last1=Crerar |first1=Pippa |last2=Edwardes |first2=Charlotte |title=Sadiq Khan says 'I'm like a stressed Victorian dad' in revealing interview about his family and religion |website=London Evening Standard |date=13 July 2016 |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/mayor/sadiq-khan-says-im-like-a-stressed-victorian-dad-in-revealing-interview-where-he-talks-about-his-a3294436.html |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160714151534/http://www.standard.co.uk/news/mayor/sadiq-khan-says-im-like-a-stressed-victorian-dad-in-revealing-interview-where-he-talks-about-his-a3294436.html |archivedate=14 July 2016 |df=dmy-all }} ==See also== * [[London mayoral election, 2016]] * [[List of British Pakistanis]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ===Sources=== {{Refbegin}} * {{cite book |last=Hill |first=Dave |year=2016 |title=Zac Versus Sadiq: The Fight to Become London Mayor |location=Not specified |publisher=Double Q |isbn=978-1-911079-20-0 |ref=harv}} {{Refend}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Sadiq Khan}} * {{Official website|http://www.sadiq.london/}} * [http://www.sadiq.london/ Sadiq Khan – Labour Candidate for Mayor of London] official site {{UK MP links| parliament = sadiq-khan/1577|hansard=|hansardcurr=4801|guardian=8847/sadiq-khan|publicwhip=Sadiq_Khan|theywork=sadiq_khan|record=Sadiq-Khan/Tooting/272|bbc=35774.stm|journalisted =sadiq-khan}} * [https://twitter.com/SadiqKhan @SadiqKhan Verified Twitter Account] * [https://twitter.com/MayorofLondon @MayorofLondon Official Verified Twitter Account] {{s-start}} {{s-par|uk}} {{s-bef|before=[[Tom Cox (politician)|Tom Cox]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)|Member of Parliament]]

{{Infobox person | name = Saleh al-Ali
{{lang|ar|صالح العلي}} | image = Saleh al-Ali.jpg | image_size = 250 | caption = Saleh al-Ali during the rebellion of 1919 | birth_name = Saleh Ahmad al-Ali | birth_date = 1884 | birth_place = [[Al-Shaykh Badr]], [[Ottoman Syria]] | death_date = 13 {{death year and age|1950|1884|4}} | death_place = [[Tartus]], [[Syria]] | resting_place = | organization = | occupation = | known_for = Commander of the [[Syrian Revolt of 1919]] | spouse = | children = | parents = | signature = | signature_size = }} '''Saleh al-Ali''' or '''Shaykh Saleh Ahmad al-Ali''' ({{lang-ar|الشيخ صالح أحمد العلي}}) (1884 in [[Al-Shaykh Badr]] – 13 April 1950 in [[Tartus]]) was a prominent [[Syrian people|Syrian]] [[Alawi]] leader who commanded the [[Syrian Revolt of 1919]], one of the first rebellions against the [[French Mandate of Syria and Lebanon|French mandate of Syria]] before the [[Great Syrian Revolt]].{{cite book | last = Moubayed | first =Sami M. | authorlink = Sami Moubayed | title = Steel & Silk: Men & Women Who Shaped Syria 1900-2000 | publisher = Cune Press | isbn = 1-885942-41-9 | pages = 363–364 | year = 2006}} ==Background== Saleh al-Ali was born in 1884 to a family of Alawi notables from [[Al-Shaykh Badr]], in the [[Syrian Coastal Mountain Range]] in northwest. He reportedly clashed with the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottomans]] in 1918 before their withdrawal from Syria,{{cite book | last = Moosa | first =Matti | title = Extremist Shiites: The Ghulat Sects | publisher = Syracuse University Press | isbn = 0-8156-2411-5 | pages = 282–283 | year = 1987}} killing two Ottoman soldiers who were harassing a wife of his father. This act gained him a local reputation as a rebel. After his father's death, he built a shrine for him and reportedly performed miracles at the site, according to local legend.{{cite book|last1=Douwes|first1=Dick|editor=Farhad Daftary|chapter=Modern History of the Nizari Ismailis of Syria|title=A Modern History of the Ismailis: Continuity and Change in a Muslim Community|date=2011|publisher=I. B. Tauris|page=33|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sf9fAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT48&lpg=PT48&dq=Ismaili+villages+Akkar&source=bl&ots=ercLZGYoQM&sig=PD_CQ0aQ0tIYKkk78XJ7HiX5bmY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAmoVChMIqaiBsLSdyAIVhBweCh1gWA2W#v=onepage&q=Ismaili%20villages%20Akkar&f=false}} ==Rebellion against the French== {{main|Syrian Revolt of 1919}} ===Start of the rebellion=== {{see also|Franco-Syrian War}} In 1918 the French occupied the Syrian coast and began to move into the interior. On December 15, 1918, Saleh al-Ali called for a meeting of prominent Alawi notables in the town of Sheikh Badr. Al-Ali alerted the attendees that the French had occupied the Syrian coast with the intention of separating the region from the rest of the country, and urged them to revolt and expel the French from Syria. When the French authorities heard of the meeting, they sent a force from [[Al-Qadmus]] to the town of Sheikh Badr in order to arrest Saleh al-Ali. Al-Ali and his men ambushed the force at the village of Niha, west of [[Wadi al-Oyoun]]. The French forces were defeated and suffered more than 35 casualties. ===Organizing the rebellion=== [[File:Syrian nationalists.jpg|thumb|Seated from left to right: [[Shukri al-Quwatli]] (future president), [[Saadallah al-Jabiri]] (future prime minister), [[Rida al-Shurbaji]] (co-founder of the National Bloc), Sheikh Saleh al-Ali, commander of the Syrian Coastal Revolt of 1919. Standing are Hajj [[Adib Kheir]] (left) and [[Ibrahim Hananu]], commander of the [[Aleppo Revolt]]]] After the initial victory, al-Ali started to organize his rebels into a disciplined force, with its own general command and military ranks. The army was supported by the local population, and some women supplied water and food and replaced the men at work in the fields. Al-Ali also allied himself with the [[Hananu Revolt|rebellion]] of [[Ibrahim Hananu]] in Aleppo, the uprising in [[Talkalakh]] by the Dandashi tribe and the revolt in [[Antioch]] by [[Subhi Barakat]]. He also received funds and arms from [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk|Kemal Atatürk]] of [[Turkey]] which was also at [[Franco-Turkish War|war with France]] at the time. In July 1919, in retaliation to French attacks against rebel positions, al-Ali attacked and occupied several [[Ismaili]] villages that were allied to the French. A truce was concluded between the two, but the French violated it by occupying and burning the village of Kaf al-Jaz. Al-Ali retaliated by attacking and occupying al-Qadmus from which the French conducted their military operations against him. ===Final stages=== The balance of power began to shift in favor of the French after they conquered [[Damascus]], defeating a makeshift army at the [[Battle of Maysalun]] on 24 July 1920. In November, General [[Henri Gouraud (French Army officer)|Henri Gouraud]] mounted a full-fledged campaign against Saleh al-Ali's forces in the [[An-Nusayriyah Mountains]]. They entered al-Ali's village of Ash-Shaykh Badr and arrested many Alawi notables. Al-Ali fled to the north, but a large French force overran his positions and al-Ali went into hiding. A French [[court-martial]] convened in [[Latakia]] and sentenced him to death [[trial in absentia|''in absentia'']]. ===Later years=== [[File:Sheikh Saleh al-Ali.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Sheikh]] Saleh al-Ali]] Al-Ali remained in hiding until General Gouraud issued a general amnesty in 1922. He returned to his home and abstained from all political activity until his death on 13 April 1950 in [[Tartus]]. ==Legacy== Saleh Al-Ali became a celebrated figure after the Syria's independence. Al-Ali, in his first public appearance since 1922, was a guest of honor of president [[Shukri al-Quwatli]] at the [[Evacuation Day (Syria)|Evacuation Day]] celebrations on 17 April 1946. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ali, Saleh al-}} [[Category:1884 births]] [[Category:1950 deaths]] [[Category:Arabs of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:Syrian military personnel]] [[Category:Syrian Alawites]] [[Category:People from Tartus Governorate]] [[Category:People sentenced to death in absentia]] [[Category:Syrian nationalists]] [[Category:People of the Franco-Syrian War]]
