{{About|the British former civil servant|the Australian kickboxer|Steve Moxon}} {{EngvarB|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}}
'''Steve Moxon''' is a British former civil servant who first came to prominence as a [[whistleblower]] in March 2004 while he was employed as a caseworker at the [[Home Office]], which is the ministerial department of the United Kingdom that handles immigration, security, and law and order. Since being dismissed from his job at the Home Office and accepting an out-of-court settlement to an employment tribunal case he brought against his former employer, he has worked as an independent researcher on the relationship between the sexes. He was selected as a [[UK Independence Party]] (UKIP) candidate for the 2012 local elections in [[Sheffield]], but was forced to stand as an independent candidate after UKIP deselected him following comments that he made on his blog about the Norwegian mass-murderer [[Anders Breivik]]. Moxon has written two books: one on immigration and the other on the science of the relationship between the sexes. The former attracted praise from some critics, but was criticised by others as "highly selective" and [[Islamophobia|Islamophobic]]. The latter has been described as "singularly odd" and "wilfully controversial".
==Home Office== Moxon came to public prominence as a whistleblower in March 2004, while working at the Home Office.<ref name=Wainwright>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/the-northerner/2012/may/02/ukip-steve-moxon-whistleblower-home-office-beverley-hughes|title=Sheffield UKIP candidate sacked over Breivik comments|first=Martin|last=Wainwright|work=The Guardian|date=2 May 2012|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref><ref name=BBC/> Moxon was a caseworker in the Home Office's Immigration and Nationality Directorate in Sheffield.<ref>{{cite book|title=Trading Information|first=Nicholas|last=Jones|location=London|publisher=Politico's Publishing|year=2006|isbn=978-1842750902|page=227}}</ref> He claimed that immigration checks had been waived for people from the [[A8 countries|eight countries]] in central and eastern Europe that were due to join the [[European Union]] in May of that year, so as to make migration flows following EU enlargement look less dramatic.<ref name=BBC>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-south-yorkshire-17911131|title=Sheffield UKIP candidate removed over Breivik blog post|work=BBC News|date=1 May 2012|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3589261.stm|title=Timeline: Immigration row|work=BBC News|date=17 June 2004|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> The allegations were published in the ''[[Sunday Times]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/node/147491|title=Watching brief – Amanda Platell on the agenda-setting Sunday Times|first=Amanda|last=Platell|work=New Statesman|date=15 March 2004|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> Moxon's revelations, along with those of two other whistleblowers, resulted in the resignation of junior minister [[Beverley Hughes]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/3589617.stm|title=Whistleblower: 'I am vindicated'|work=BBC News|date=1 April 2004|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2004/apr/01/immigrationpolicy.immigrationandpublicservices1|title=Explained: the Hughes affair|first=Matthew|last=Tempest|work=The Guardian|date=1 April 2004|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref> Moxon himself was dismissed from his civil service job.<ref name=Fight>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/south_yorkshire/3943489.stm|title=Whistleblower will fight sacking|work=BBC News|date=1 August 2004|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> Initially, he was feted by figures from the opposition [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] including [[Michael Howard]] and [[David Davis (British politician)|David Davis]], but they distanced themselves from him when it was revealed that Moxon had e-mailed the website of the BBC's ''[[Panorama (TV series)|Panorama]]'' programme claiming that: "An international alliance of Islamic Year Zeros feverishly exporting death to 'infidel' and non-fundamentalist Muslims alike...eventually will have to be silenced by nuclear weapons".<ref name=Wainwright/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2004/mar/11/conservatives.immigrationpolicy|title=Howard caught out after championing whistleblower|first=Sarah|last=Hall|work=The Guardian|date=11 March 2004|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref>
Moxon subsequently wrote a book, ''The Great Immigration Scandal'',<ref name=Wainwright/> which was published by Imprint Academic in August 2004.<ref name=Scandal>{{cite web|url=http://www.imprint.co.uk/books/moxon.html|title=The Great Immigration Scandal|publisher=Imprint Academic|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> David Davis had been scheduled to chair the launch event for the book, but withdrew "amid claims that the book was an Islamophobic rant". A Conservative Party spokesman reported that Davis "had agreed to go provisionally and talk in favour of Steve as a whistleblower. But that was before he saw the contents of the book. He then felt unable to attend". According to ''[[The Guardian]]'', the book "claims the term 'paki' is not racist; predicts immigration leading to Ulster-style civil war; and Asians are more likely to be organised criminals".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2004/sep/07/immigrationandpublicservices.conservatives|title=Tory asylum assault goes awry|first1=Michael|last1=White|first2=Vikram|last2=Dodd|work=The Guardian|date=7 September 2004|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] MP [[Frank Field (British politician)|Frank Field]] reviewed the book for the ''Sunday Times'', describing it as a "slow-burn Molotov cocktail on immigration".<ref>{{cite news|title=Policy, what policy?|first=Frank|last=Field|work=Sunday Times|date=17 October 2004|page=45}}</ref> It received positive endorsements from commentators including [[Andrew Green, Baron Green of Deddington|Andrew Green]] of [[MigrationWatch UK]] and [[David George Green|David G. Green]] of [[Civitas (think tank)|Civitas]].<ref name=Scandal/> Academic Neil Lunt, reviewing the book in the journal ''Political Studies Review'', gave it one star and wrote that: "Scandals are everywhere and doomsday scenarios litter the text. There is a lack of clear and judicious argument: referencing is highly selective, and there are frequent sweeping and unsupported statements. Moxon fails to convey an understanding of many issues including structural discrimination, the 1951 Refugee Convention and Britain's relationship to Empire. In some places the text is well written; in others it resembles a teenager's diary. Further, alongside the now familiar caricatures of migrant scroungers, there were also inappropriate and offensive references ''vis-à-vis'' women, disability and race".<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Great Immigration Scandal by Steve Moxon|first=Neil|last=Lunt|journal=Political Studies Review|volume=3|issue=3|year=2005|pages=407–408|doi=10.1111/j.1478-9299.2005.00030_2.x}}</ref>
Following his sacking, Moxon announced that he would take the Home Office to an [[employment tribunal]] for unfair dismissal.<ref name=Fight/> In July 2005, on the day the tribunal was scheduled for, Moxon and the Home Office reached an out-of-court settlement. Moxon reportedly accepted a settlement of between £40,000 and £50,000, and signed a [[Gag order|gagging clause]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.personneltoday.com/hr/home-office-whistleblowing-case-settled-out-of-court/|title=Home Office whistleblowing case settled out of court|first=Mike|last=Berry|work=Personnel Today|date=4 July 2005|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref>
In a study of media coverage of whistleblowing, academics Karin Wahl-Jorgensen and Joanne Hunt use Moxon's case as an example of how, in a sample covering the period 1 January 1997 to 20 March 2009, "whistleblower stories featured prominently in tabloids when they chimed with the political orientation of that particular newspaper". They note "the right-leaning, anti-immigration ''[[Daily Express|Express]]''' coverage" of his whistleblowing. They also note that the ''Express'' compared the whistleblowing of Moxon with that of [[Clare Short]] and [[Katherine Gunn]]. The newspaper described Moxon as "brave" and suggested that he "said what he did to protect his country", and Gunn as "acting on principle", while it claimed Short's revelations about the British government's illegal surveillance at the United Nations "hurt her country".<ref>{{cite journal|title=Journalism, accountability and the possibilities for structural critique: A case study of coverage of whistleblowing|first1=Karin|last1=Wahl-Jorgensen|first2=Joanne|last2=Hunt|journal=Journalism|volume=13|issue=4|pages=399–416|year=2012|doi=10.1177/1464884912439135}}</ref>
==UK Independence Party== In 2012, Moxon was due to stand as a UK Independence Party candidate in [[Sheffield City Council election, 2012|local elections in Sheffield]], but he was deselected by the party after endorsing the analysis contained in the "manifesto" of Norwegian mass-murderer Anders Breivik. Moxon had written on his blog that: "That pretty well everyone—myself not excluded—recoiled at his actions, does not belie the accuracy of Breivik's research and analysis in his 'manifesto', which is in line with most scholarship in respect of both Political Correctness and Islam".<ref name=Wainwright/> Moxon and UKIP both noted that he had not said that he condoned Breivik's crimes, but the party noted that "he has made a number of remarks on subjects such as the Breivik manifesto and Islam that are at odds with UKIP policy and perspective".<ref name=BBC/> He eventually stood as an independent candidate,<ref name=McSmith/> winning 363 votes in the [[Dore and Totley]] ward.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/news/local/election-results-sheffield-s-ex-council-leader-paul-scriven-loses-his-seat-1-4517468|title=Election Results: Sheffield's ex Council leader Paul Scriven loses his seat|work=The Star|date=4 May 2012|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref>
According to Moxon's personal website, his politics were originally "centre-Left/'green'". He states that he was "a [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal-Democrat]] activist for the best part of two decades".<ref name=Profile/> According to a 2004 article in the ''[[Sheffield Star]]'', Moxon also "claims to have played a part in the backroom team for the election campaign of [[Sheffield Hallam (UK Parliament constituency)|Hallam]] MP [[Richard Allan]]".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thestar.co.uk/what-s-on/out-about/i-ve-no-regrets-about-speaking-out-says-whistle-blower-1-320223|title=I've no regrets about speaking out says whistle blower|work=The Star|date=9 March 2004|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref>
==Independent researcher== In an interview with the ''[[Evening Standard]]'' published in 2007, Moxon stated that he didn't "have a particular interest" in debates about immigration, noting that his passion was instead for psychology, and that he had previously dropped out of a psychology degree course.<ref>{{cite news|title=I've never regretted blowing the whistle on migrants|first=Keith|last=Dovkants|work=London Evening Standard|date=31 October 2007|page=18}}</ref> Moxon now describes himself as an independent researcher.<ref name=Profile>{{cite web|url=http://stevemoxon.co.uk/profile.php|title=Profile|publisher=Steve Moxon|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> He stated in 2007 that the payout he received from the Home Office as a result of their out-of-court settlement enabled him "to not have to work for a while, so that's when I started writing".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/pandora/pandora-home-office-whistleblower-declares-war-on-feminism-764114.html|title=Pandora: Home Office whistle-blower declares war on feminism|first= Henry|last=Deedes|work=The Independent|date=10 December 2007|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> In 2008, his second book, ''The Woman Racket: The New Science Explaining How the Sexes Relate at Work, at Play and in Society'', was published by Imprint Academic.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imprint.co.uk/books/TWR.html|title=The Woman Racket|publisher=Imprint Academic|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> According to [[Andy McSmith]] of ''[[The Independent]]'', the book expounds Moxon's "thesis that men are the disadvantaged sex".<ref name=McSmith>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/diary/diary-the-candidate-even-ukip-found-too-embarrassing-7707446.html|title=Diary: The candidate even UKIP found too embarrassing|first=Andy|last=McSmith|work=The Independent|date=3 May 2012|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> In a review, philosopher George Williamson wrote that it was "a singularly odd book". He argued that, despite the book's subtitle, "the science presented isn't all that new, nor is much science presented" and that "there are myriad concerns with the details of the science <nowiki>[Moxon]</nowiki> invokes".<ref>{{cite journal|title=Review – The Woman Racket|first=George|last=Williamson|journal=Metapsychology|volume=12|issue=19|year=2008|url=http://metapsychology.mentalhelp.net/poc/view_doc.php?type=book&id=4221}}</ref> Novelist [[Lionel Shriver]] wrote in the ''Guardian'' that it was a "wilfully controversial book claiming that men are the downtrodden sex, so pretentious and badly written that even the happy prospect of finding it offensive couldn't pull me through".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2008/feb/14/law|title=Finally, a jury can decide whether a reprobate dared to throw her apple core to the ground|first=Lionel|last=Shriver|work=The Guardian|date=14 February 2008|accessdate=6 August 2015}}</ref>
In 2012, Moxon was ranked by an anti-feminist website as one of the ten most powerful people in the [[men's rights movement]].<ref name=Rickman>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2012/11/21/steve-moxon-women-business_n_2170854.html|title=Women 'Incapable' Of Becoming Bosses at Work, Steve Moxon Tells Parliamentary Committee|first=Dina|last=Rickman|work=HuffPost|date=21 November 2012|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref> He has also given evidence to a [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] [[Business, Innovation and Skills Committee|Business, Innovation and Skills Select Committee]] inquiry into women in the workplace. It was reported that Moxon had suggested to the committee that women were "incapable" of rising to senior management positions. Feminist writer [[Laura Bates]] argued that it was worrying that the select committee "should be seeking out the view of someone who has openly expressed these opinions and demonstrated that he is prejudiced against women as a gender".<ref name=Rickman/> Committee member [[Robin Walker]] noted that Moxon was chosen to ensure "a wide range of views" was represented, but that "He was definitely on the extreme end and he didn't come across as very reasonable at all".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marieclaire.co.uk/news/world/539545/male-academic-says-women-are-biologically-unfit-to-operate-at-senior-levels-of-business.html#IxVoqSspVJaFMZZj.99|title= Male academic says women are 'biologically unfit' to operate at senior levels of business|first=Natasha|last=Wynarczyk|work=Marie Claire|date=13 November 2012|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref>
Moxon made a complaint to the [[BBC Trust]] about coverage of the select committee's inquiry in an episode of the BBC Radio 4 programme ''[[Woman's Hour]]'', broadcast in December 2012. He complained that he had not in fact claimed that women were incapable of becoming bosses. Moxon's claim that the programme "had over many years displayed unfairness to men generically and had dismissed scientific research on men/women" was dismissed, as were three of Moxon's other complaints, including that about the characterisation of his evidence to the inquiry. His complaint that the presenter misreprestented him as "a man who describes himself as an academic" was, however, upheld. In his complaint, Moxon stated that he describes himself as an "independent cross-disciplinary researcher/writer on the biological roots of human sociality with a particular interest in the sexes", and noted that he did not have a university affiliation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://downloads.bbc.co.uk/bbctrust/assets/files/pdf/appeals/esc_bulletins/2013/apr_may.pdf|title=Editorial Standards Findings: Appeals to the Trust and other editorial issues considered by the Editorial Standards Committee|publisher=BBC Trust|pages=13–24|date=June 2013|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/bbc-watchdog-rules-in-favour-of-womans-hour-after-man-complains-of-sexism-8665560.html|title=BBC watchdog rules in favour of Woman's Hour after man complains of sexism|first=Matilda|last=Battersby|work=The Independent|date=19 June 2013|accessdate=5 August 2015}}</ref>
